justification: “To illustrate how affective bias can distort optimal decision-making, we consider the response of human participants in the tone-discrimination task of Aylward et al. (2019a),” indicating this task is used to quantify affective bias.

The paper notes that “this approach has been used to examine the response biases and anhedonia by Pizzagalli et al., 2005,” referring to the probabilistic reward task as the instrument for assessing anhedonia.

“To measure the subjective utility functions of participants, it is necessary to include Prospect Theory measures… Presenting a series of lottery choices… it is possible to measure each participant's subjective utility function,” showing that lottery-choice tasks grounded in Prospect Theory are used to obtain this measure.
